A fight to win fundamental labor law reform for the first time in 85 years. It‚Äôs a fight we can only win with the solidarity and active participation of workers everywhere. I can‚Äôt wait. 16//

As we honor the fight of workers past and present, we must recommit ourselves to a new fight in the months and years ahead: a fight to restore workers‚Äô voice and power in society; a fight to rebuild the American middle class in a way that reduces racial and gender injustice. 15/
America‚Äôs workers deserve access to a fair economy; an economy that works for them as much as it does for the wealthiest among us. 14/
I continue to call on Republican leadership in the Senate to pass this bill with the urgency it requires. 13/

In February of this year, we passed the Protecting the Right to Organize Act, or the PRO Act, through the House of Representatives as part of our For the People Agenda. This bill is vital to restoring and enhancing the vision created by the Wagner Act in 1935. 12/
We must respect the will of these workers by removing barriers to forming a union and ending the egregious attacks on those simply trying to exercise their rights under the law. 11/

In a Gallup poll released this week, unions enjoy a sixty-five percent approval rating. 10/

https://news.gallup.com/poll/318980/approval-labor-unions-remains-high.aspx

Hope is not lost, however. In the last two and a half years, workers have shown their distaste for the status quo via record-setting labor unrest leading to a renewed interest in and support for unions. 9/

Corporations reportedly spend $340 million per year on union busting consultants and are charged with violating the law in 41.5 percent of union representation elections. These numbers are staggering. 8/ 

https://www.epi.org/publication/unlawful-employer-opposition-to-union-election-campaigns/
Unfortunately, due to attacks by corporations and weak labor laws, the freedom to form a union and bargain collectively is severely at risk. 7/
It is these rights that are responsible for so many of the protections we take for granted every day, like the weekend itself, prohibitions on child labor, minimum wages and so much more. 6/

Put simply, there is no other mechanism that can empower workers in their own workplaces and in society at large like the ability to come together to form a union and bargain collectively with their employer. 5/
As farm workers, meat processors, and grocery workers stand up to minimize the risks they are taking to keep us fed; as postal workers quite literally sound the alarm to save our democracy. 4/

While this pandemic prevents our parades, it also brings into sharp focus why unions are so important: as educators fight for the health and safety of their students, their colleagues and all of our families. 3/

This Labor Day feels so different, the first in my lifetime when the workers of this great city of Detroit will not be gathering downtown to celebrate & honor the sacrifices made by so many who came before us in the fight for workers‚Äô rights, the dignity of work, a just world. 2/

As the union membership share among private-sector workers has decreased, the share of private-sector workers with defined benefit retirement plans has also fallen. In 2018, just 22% of workers had defined benefit plans. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EhUlkSSWAAEzVGM.png

94% of union workers have access to employer-provided health insurance compared to only 68% of nonunion workers, while 91% of union workers have access to paid sick leave compared to only 73% of nonunion workers. The #coronavirus pandemic underscores the importance of both.
As union membership has decreased, the share of income going to the top 10% of Americans has increased. In 2018, 48% of income went to the top 10%. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EhUlah9WAAEkpJ_.jpg

Black & Hispanic workers get a larger boost from unionization because collective bargaining lifts their wages more. Black union workers are paid 13.7% more than their Black nonunion peers, & Hispanic union workers are paid 20.1% more than their Hispanic nonunion peers.
An average worker covered by a union earns 11.2% more in wages than a peer with similar education & experience in the same industry who is not covered by a union.
